titlestmt.titleproper: Ford Foundation records, Office of the President, Office Files of H. Rowan Gaither
A Guide to the Ford Foundation records, Office of the President, Office Files of H. Rowan Gaither FA621
titlestmt.author: Arranged and described by Nancy E. Weltchek, Ford Foundation Archives, September 1985. Revised, F. Coleman, May 1996. Revised by Lucas Buresch, Rockefeller Archive Center, June 2013.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2015-09-19 01:01:54 -0400.

did.unittitle: Ford Foundation records, Office of the President, Office Files of H. Rowan Gaither
did.abstract:
The office files of H. Rowan Gaither cover the years 1947 to 1959, with the bulk of the records dating from 1951 to 1956. The arrangement of the records closely follows an outline that was found enclosed with the files. Presumably the outline described the order in which the files were arranged by Gaither's secretary, Ann Eggars. (Archives was unable to locate this outline as of May 1996.) The files consist mainly of correspondence, reports and notes.
Records maintained by Gaither pertaining to the 1949 Study Committee, aka the Gaither Committee, were transferred to the record series for the Study Committee. Some material from the Fund for Adult Education (FAE) folders in series II, boxes 2 and 3, was copied and placed in the F AE grant files, P A51 0-0026 and P A530-0206. Speeches, reports and publications were transferred to their respective collections in the Archives. Transfers are noted on cross-reference sheets in Gaither's records. Appendices to this register list Gaither's speeches and reports and other staff and consultant reports that were transferred to the Ford Foundation Archives' Speech Collection and Unpublished Reports Collection.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Completion of a use agreement is required prior to providing scholarly access. See RAC Head of Reference (or applicable designee) for details.
Ford Foundation holds title, copyright and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them.

The Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish material from the collection for scholarly purposes. Permission to publish extensive excerpts, or material in its entirety, will be referred to the Ford Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Material more than ten years old is open for scholarly research.
Select individual files are restricted, as noted. Permission to access these files must be obtained from the Ford Foundation before scholarly access is permitted.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: H. Rowan Gaither, Ford Foundation President from March 1953 to October 1956, also held the following positions in the Foundation:
H. Rowan Gaither was born on November 23, 1909. He received his A.B. and LL.B. degrees from the University of California, in 1929 and 1933 respectively. He was admitted to the California bar in 1933.

Before coming to the Ford Foundation, Gaither followed careers in law, banking, and public service. From 1933 to 1936, Gaither served as Special Assistant to the General Counsel of the Farm Credit Administration in Washington.

In 1936 he returned to California where he became partner in the San Francisco law firm of Cooley, Crowley & Supple, later Cooley, Crowley & Gaither. From 1942 to 1945 Gather, on leave from his law firm, served as Assistant Director of the Radiation Laboratory at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. He was awarded the Presidential Certificate of Merit for his service in this organization.

In 1948, Gather helped to organize the Rand Corporation, and was appointed Chairman of the Board. In that same year, he was asked by the trustees of the Ford Foundation "to organize and direct a planning study of policy and program for the Foundation." (Report of the Study... 1949, p. 9) Gaither served as Chairman of the Study Committee and Director of the staff of the Committee.

In March 1953, Gaither was appointed President of the Ford Foundation. He served in this position until his resignation on October 1, 1956. On April 22, 1956, Gaither had been named Chairman of the Board of Trustees, a post he held until 1958. Gaither continued to serve as a Ford Foundation trustee until 1960.
During the last year of his life, Gaither was intermittently active in the venture-capital field with the firm of Draper, Gaither and Anderson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The office files of H. Rowan Gaither consist of 5 1/2 linear feet (15 archives boxes) of correspondence, notes and reports. They reflect the early years of the Ford Foundation afar its expansion in 1949 from a local Michigan charity to a national and international philanthropic organization. In 1950, the Report of the Study for the Ford Foundation on Policy and Program was issued by the Study Committee, which was chaired by Gaither.

This report proposed five program areas to be the focal points of the Ford Foundation's operations. In 1950, they were adopted by the Foundation Trustees. They were: Area I: The Establishment of Peace; Area II: The Strengthening of Democracy; Area III: The Strengthening of the Economy; Area IV: Education in a Democratic Society; and Area V: Individual Behavior and Human Relations. The Gaither office files focus on the implementation of these five program areas. The records demonstrate" the influence of, but do not contain, the records of the Study Committee which constitute a separate record sense.

Program Area One - The Establishment of Peace - was intended to foster international understanding, maintain world peace, and combat communist threats to the western world, by strengthening politically and economically the position of the free world, particularly the uncommitted developing countries. The projects were designed to work toward solutions to these problems and fell under the following categories: Overseas Development, Overseas Training and Research, International Affairs, and the Exchange of Persons. Program Area One records contain material relating to the planning and development of these subdivisions. They are particularly valuable in demonstrating the importance that the Foundation placed on gaining greater knowledge of the Soviet Union. The records also include letters from Douglas Ensmiger, the first Ford Foundation representative in India. His correspondence concerns the Foundation's Area One developmental activities in India, which were intended to counterbalance similar assistance from the Soviet Union.

Program Area Two - The Strengthening of Democracy - was designed to safeguard individual civil liberties in a democratic society, and to strengthen the institutions and democratic processes themselves. Program Area Two records include material on the Fund for Adult Education, the Fund for the Republic, and the TV-Radio Workshop.

Program Area Three - The Strengthening of the Economy - was aimed at achieving a productive domestic and world economy in the face of the United States' military and economic commitments abroad and at home. Program Area Three records include material on Resources for the Future.

Program Area Four - Education in a Democratic Society - considered education to be the most important element for the improvement of human welfare and the guarantee of democracy. Program Area Four records include material on the Fund for the Advancement of Education and Intercultural Publications.

Program Area Five - Individual Behavior and Human Relations - addressed the need for knowledge of human behavior and for its application on all program areas of the Foundation. Program Area Five records include material on a controversial grant to the University of Chicago Law School. One purpose of the project was to "study the actual operation of the jury system". In 1954, as part of the research, the deliberations of a jury in Wichita, Kansas were recorded without the jurors' knowledge. Public outrage resulted and eventually the case was investigated by the United States Senate Sub-Committee on Internal Security. The Ford Foundation received much criticism for having funded the project. This occurrence raised basic policy questions regarding the Foundation's relationship to its grantees, and the limits of Foundation accountability to, and responsibility for, grantee action. The incident and the questions it raised are well documented in the Area Five series.

The Ford Foundation itself came under Congressional investigation during the 1950s. In the wake of the Cox Committee (House Select Committee to Investigate Tax-Exempt Foundations and Comparable Organizations)and Reece Committee (House Special Committee to Investigate Tax-Exempt Foundations) hearings, the Foundation's Board and officers recognized the need to educate the public about the benefits of organized philanthropy and commissioned a study on this subject. The background material for the study is contained in the Program Area Two series. Gather's files on the Cox and Reece Committees are located in Series VI, Administration, sub series on Public Relations (boxes 11 and 12).

Series VI, Administration, is comprised of five subseries: Personnel; Grant Policies and Procedures; Organization and Administration; Financial and Legal; and Public Relations. The records in this series, especially the Organization and Administration subseries, provide a good source for researchers investigating such topics as institution building and organization and management. This sub series draws on and applies the guidelines set forth by the Study Committee’s report. Many reports from this sub series have been transferred to the Archives' Reports Collection. The remaining material complements the reports. The Administration series also contains a file on the financial relationship between the Ford Foundation and the Ford Motor Company during the years 1947 to 1956.

As a whole, Gaither's office files document the Foundation's unique role in the history of philanthropy, conveying the sense of limitless possibility that permeated the Foundation in its early years. They reflect the Foundation's resolve to act as an institution dedicated to promoting the public well-being and contributing to the solution of problems both national and international in scope, completely separate from the United States government.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Appendix A, B, and C describe materials removed from the original collection by Ford Foundation staff.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be restricted from scholarly research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment.
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be restricted from scholarly research at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/RAC Head of Reference.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files and officers papers were transferred to, and accessioned by, RAC beginning in 2011. Accessions continue as necessary.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The office files of H. Rowan Gaither, Office of the President, are divided into eight subject series. Although Gaither did not become President until 1953, the records document his Foundation activities from 1950 to 1959, with the bulk of the records from 1951 to 1956, and include some earlier material, which he inherited from his predecessor, Paul Hoffman. The series are:

I. Area One: The Establishment of Peace II. Area Two: The Strengthening of Democracy III. Area Three: The Strengthening of the Economy IV. Area Four: Education in a Democratic Society V. Area Five: Individual Behavior and Human Relations VI. Administration VII. Non-Program Suggestions VIII. Ford Motor Company Reports
Series I: Area One files (1951-1956). Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject.
Series ll: Area Two files (1949-1956). Four subseries, as follows:

• Program Material (1949-1956). Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject. • The Fund for Adult Education (1951-1956). Arranged chronologically. • The Fund for the Republic (1951-1956). Arranged chronologically. • TV-Radio Workshop (1953-1956). Arranged chronologically.
Series III: Area Three files (1951-1956). Two subseries, as follows:
• Program Material (1951-1956). Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject. • Resources for the Future (1953-1956). Arranged chronologically.
Series IV: Area Four files (1951-1956). Three subseries, as follows:

• Program Material (1951-1956). Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject. • The Fund for the Advancement of Education (1951-1956). Arranged chronologically. • Intercultural Publications (1953-1955). Arranged chronologically.
Series V: Area Five files (1951-1956). Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject.
Series VI: Administration files (1947-1958). .Five subseries, each arranged chronologically, as follows:
• Personnel (1951-1956) • Grant Policies and Procedures (1952-1956) • Organization and Administration (1951-1956) • Financial and Legal (1947-1956) • Public Relations (1949-1959)

Series VlI: Non-Program Suggestions (1952-1956). The material consists of program proposals which were not funded, and funded projects that did not fall under the usual program areas. Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject.
Series VIII: Ford Motor Company Reports (1946-1955). Annual and financial reports arranged chronologically.

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by subject, then chronologically within each subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correespondence between H. Rowan Gaither, Bernard L. Gladieux, and John B. Howard re: "whether the Ford Foundation could act as a channel for the expenditure of CIA funds". Also includes notes from a April 3, 1951 conference with Walter Bedell "Beetle" Smith and Allen Dulles re: possible projects.
